SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: :ibox:This problem has TWO parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
In “When I Grow Up,” what does the speaker's statement that he will “be all of them” most reveal?

A.Choice: He is very interested in music.

Key.Rationale: Even though it is a true statement it does not encompass all of the speaker's interests.

B.Choice: He wants to live by the sea.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not relate to the given phrase from the poem.
This choice does not relate to the given phrase from the poem.
The speaker identifies many different careers and wants to “be all of them,” supporting the idea that he has numerous, varied interests.

Content: What evidence from the poem best supports the answer in Part One? Choose one answer.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not support the correct answer in Part One; it does not indicate how the speaker has many interests.
Although this option does reveal two interests that the speaker has, it does not support the description from Part One that the speaker has many different interests.
Although this option does reveal two interests that the speaker has, it does not support the description from Part One that the speaker has many different interests.
“A dozen things more.” represents the speaker's interest in many jobs he wishes to have as an adult.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: What is the best summary of “When I Grow Up”?

A.Choice: A boy goes on a variety of adventures using only his imagination.

Key.Rationale: This choice misinterprets the main events of the poem.

B.Choice: A boy tells stories of all the people he has met during a year.

Key.Rationale: This choice misinterprets the main events of the poem.

C.Choice: A boy thinks of the many different places he could live one day.

Key.Rationale: This choice misinterprets the main events of the poem.

D.Choice: A boy thinks about the different jobs he could have when he is older.

Key.Rationale: This choice accurately states the main points of the poem.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: The meaning of the suffix “-ery” helps the reader know the word “crockery” means

Key.Rationale: The suffix “-ery” means “collection” and is part of the meaning of the word in question.
This choice does not match the meaning of the suffix “-ery” and does not make sense in the context of the poem.
This choice does not match the meaning of the suffix “-ery” and does not make sense in the context of the poem.
This choice does not match the meaning of the suffix “-ery” and does not make sense in the context of the poem.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Read these lines from “General Store.”

:box:“It will be my store, and I will say:
'What can I do for you today?'”
What do these lines most reveal about the speaker?

A.Choice: The speaker is confused about how to speak to customers.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by the given lines.

B.Choice: The speaker wants to surprise people who visit the store.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by the given lines.

C.Choice: The speaker is interested in meeting new friends.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not supported by the poem.

D.Choice: The speaker wants to be helpful to customers.

Key.Rationale: The line “What can I do for you today?” shows that the speaker wants to be helpful.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which lines from “General Store” support the inference that the speaker will do most of the work?

A.Choice:
“Sarsaparilla for picnic lunches,
Bananas and rubber boots in bunches.”

Key.Rationale: This choice merely lists items the speaker will have in the store.

B.Choice:
“There'll be a little of everything:
Bolts of calico; balls of string;”

Key.Rationale: This choice merely lists items the speaker will have in the store.

C.Choice:
“I'll fix the window and dust each shelf,
And take the money in all myself.”

Key.Rationale: Tthe lines show chores that the speaker will do (fix the window, dust each shelf, take in the money).

D.Choice:
“Jars of peppermint; tins of tea;
Pots and kettles and crockery;”

Key.Rationale: This choice merely lists items the speaker will have in the store.

Topics: Reading Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes and topics (e.g., opposition of good and evil) and patterns of events (e.g., the quest) in stories, myths, and traditional literature from different cultures.
Content: :ibox:This problem has TWO parts. Answer Part One and then answer Part Two.
How is the topic having goals to achieve conveyed throughout both of the poems?

A.Choice: by the speakers' desiring to create objects of value

Key.Rationale: This choice is unsupported by details in either poem.

B.Choice: by the speakers' reflecting on past events

Key.Rationale: This choice is unsupported by details in either poem.
This choice is unsupported by details in either poem.

D.Choice: by the speakers' stating future plans

Key.Rationale: Both poems state the speakers' future career plans.

Content: What two phrases from the poems support the answer in Part One? Choose two answers.

A.Choice: “With a skeleton key” from “When I Grow Up”

Key.Rationale: This choice only lists items associated with future careers that the speakers wish to have.

B.Choice: “I think I'll be all of them” from “When I Grow Up”

Key.Rationale: This choice refers to the future plans of the speaker of “When I Grow Up.”

C.Choice: “With real glass cases and counters wide” from “General Store”

Key.Rationale: This choice only lists items associated with future careers that the speakers wish to have.

D.Choice: “Some day I'm going to have a store” from “General Store”

Key.Rationale: This choice refers to the future plans of the speaker of “General Store.”

Topics: Reading Literature - Craft & Structure/Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast the point of view from which different stories are narrated, including the difference between first- and third-person narrations.
Content: Which sentences best state a comparison of the points of view used in both poems?

A.Choice: Both poems use a first person point of view. Both are told by speakers in the poems.

Key.Rationale: Both poems use the first person point of view as evidenced by both poems' use of “I” to refer to the speaker.

B.Choice: Both poems use a third person point of view. Both are told by characters in the poems.

Key.Rationale: This choice misidentifies the point of view used in both poems.

C.Choice:
“When I Grow Up” uses a first person point of view and is told by a speaker.
“General Store” uses a third person point of view and is told by a character in the poem.

Key.Rationale: This choice misidentifies the point of view used in both poems.

D.Choice:
“When I Grow Up” uses a third person point of view and is told by a character in the poem.
“General Store” uses a first person point of view and is told by a speaker.

Key.Rationale: This choice misidentifies the point of view used in both poems.

SubTopics: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
Content: The authors of the passage describe Ed Young as a “deeply thoughtful man.” Write an essay analyzing how the authors support this statement. Use evidence from the passage to support your response.
Read the sentence.
:box:“Don't eat the cookies yet,” exclaimed Grandma to the children.
Which change in punctuation shows that Grandma was surprised to find the children eating her cookies?

Key.Rationale: The revision uses incorrect punctuation and would not indicate surprise.

B.Choice: Change the comma to a question mark after y͟e͟t.

Key.Rationale: The revision uses incorrect punctuation and would not indicate surprise.

C.Choice: Change the comma to an exclamation mark after y͟e͟t.

Key.Rationale: An exclamation mark after “yet” would indicate a strong feeling such as surprise.
The revision uses incorrect punctuation and would not indicate surprise.

Content: Read the sentence.
:box:Washington, D.C., is located on the P͟o͟t͟o͟m͟a͟c r͟i͟v͟e͟r near the s͟t͟a͟t͟e of M͟a͟r͟y͟l͟a͟n͟d.
Which underlined word has a mistake in capitalization?

Key.Rationale: “Potomac” is part of a proper noun and should be capitalized.
“River” is part of a proper noun and should be capitalized.
“State” is not a proper noun and should not be capitalized.
“Maryland” is a proper noun and should be capitalized.

SubTopics: Choose words and phrases to convey ideas its conventions. precisely.
Content: Which sentence contains the most specific details?

A.Choice: Bring everything you need on the field trip.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not give specific details of what to bring.

B.Choice: Bring a bag lunch and a warm jacket on the field trip.

Key.Rationale: The sentence tells specific details of what type of meal and clothing to bring on the field trip.

C.Choice: Bring all the necessary things on the field trip.

Key.Rationale: This choice provides only vague information about what to bring.

D.Choice: Bring something to eat and something warm to wear on the field trip.

Key.Rationale: Even though this option is more specific than other options, it does not specify what type of meal or clothing to bring.

Content: Read the sentences.

:box:(1) “Where is the colored pencils?” asked Mark.
(2) “In the closet are two boxes of pencils,” Mary answered.
(3) “The pencils in one box are brand-new,” Henry added.
(4) “There are crayons in the closet too,” Mary said.
Which sentence has an error in subject-verb agreement?

Key.Rationale: “Is” is incorrect; since the subject of “pencils” is plural, the verb “is” should be changed to “are” so that there is agreement.
The verb “are” agrees with the plural subject “boxes.”
The verb “are” agrees with the plural subject “pencils.”
The verb “are” agrees with the plural subject “crayons.”
